transport.comment:
Power is equivalent to the rate at which energy is consumed. A watt-hour is a unit of energy and is defined as one watt for one hour. 

Given a LCD screen is not an energy storage device, it is inappropriate to assign it an energy rating. A LCD screen is not a battery. The only time it would be appropriate to use energy to describe an LCD screen is if you given some qualification for that, by for example, denoting over what time-period it will use that amount of energy, or if it will use that amount of energy over a full charge.

30 Watts is about right for a LCD screen, so it seems like you confused power and energy. Given this I don't see how you can possibly make a statement about what Tesla should and should not include in their car when you don't understand the physics. As T1MT1M showed, the change in range to the car is rather small.

As for the reasoning behind the screen:

> A number of the interior design solutions need more polish. However, all judges were impressed with the Tesla's unique user interface, courtesy of the giant touch screen in the center of the car that controls everything from the air-conditioning to the nav system to the sound system to the car's steering, suspension, and brake regeneration settings. The system means the Model S interior is virtually button-free, and the car has been effectively future-proofed: More functionality is only a software update away.

Read more: http://www.motortrend.com/oftheyear/car/1301_2013_motor_trend_car_of_the_year_tesla_model_s/#ixzz2zc7TsQiN


> An absolutely enormous, seventeen-inch touchscreen dominates the dashboard and features the controls for everything from the radio to the steering effort. That sounds like a recipe for disaster, but here it works wonderfully. Oh, yeah, and you can surf the Web on it, as well. "We turned a lot of preconceived notions on their head and said, 'Why does it have to be that way?'" says Tesla lead designer Franz von Holzhausen. Of course, practically every new car claims to be revolutionary. But this one actually feels like it is, to the point that many of us were reaching outside the automotive lexicon to describe it. "It reminds me of the first time I used an iPhone," gasped associate web editor Ben Timmins.

transport.comment:
For the most part, you can use any of these systems.  It's just the card that car comes with.

For instance: I drive a BMW i3.  Along with the manual and warranty information, I got 2 chargepoint cards.  I can use those at any chargepoint station once I set up my account.  However, I also have set up a blink account on my own that I also use.

Chargepoint, blink and other companies are just different networks of chargers, but the chargers themselves are generally the same.  Most cars in the US (with the exception of Tesla), use a J1772 charger for 110, 220 or 240V charging.  So, you're not worried about the brand name of the charger, as long as it's the correct charger.

There is also a different kind of charging that's referred to as Fast Charging.  You will see some differences here.  While DC Fast Charge was just set up as the US standard, some cars use different fast charge systems (CHAdeMO being the most popular other charger).  So, if I were to pull up in my BMW i3 to a fast charge system and it was CHAdeMO and not a DC Fast Charge, it wouldn't work.  These chargers are less common though, and most places that have one will soon have both.

TLDR: The network doesn't matter as long as it's the right connector/charger

transport.comment:
From reading through this thread, lots of people giving awesome advice (especially with regards to batteries) and it looks like you're well on your way to finding a system that works for you! However, if your project is several years down the road, you'll want to keep incentive deadlines in mind.

Currently, there is a 30% federal income tax credit available with no cap, but it expires at the end of 2016 and we don't know if it's going to be renewed. If at all possible, I would suggest getting your system online before then to take advantage of that credit. If your potential home needs any electrical upgrades that are "required to make the solar work", you can often lump that into the solar contract and thus take that tax credit on it. 

Contact your local utility, they will sometimes offer additional incentives beyond the typical net metering program. Your state may have an additional credit or rebate available as well. If you hire a good professional installer, they will walk you through all of the incentives available in your area and give you a ballpark of your final cost with all those incentives factored in and the ROI on your system.

transport.comment:
The hybrid system isn't as inefficient as you think.  It's worse than some of the competitors, but not by much (around 5%).  Someone needs to make new technology that is an order of magnitude better before it makes a difference.  There are many other companies with worse hybrid systems (like the ford fusion ev).

Many of the current hybrids use the hybrid synergy drive technology which is still a standard combustion engine that still contains a variable transmission to divert engine power to the wheels.  The newer hybrid tech that the Chevy Volt uses is a bit less efficient because the engine is only used to generate electricity to power the electric motor.  Obviously there will be some efficiency loss when you convert rotational power to electrical, then back to rotational.

The current versions of plug-in hybrids from toyota, honda, and nissan all use a similar HSD technology that lets the ICE power the wheels directly.  The chevy volt & ford fusion use their ICE for generating electricity, that then powers a motor to turn the wheels.  

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_Synergy_Drive

> > I've also declared there's a group of truck buyers who don't care about 300+ mile range with 5 minute refueling, and you simply don't want to acknowledge that.

> You're not going to get anything close to 300 miles of range from a battery powered truck.

That wasn't my point, though I admittedly didn't make it clear.

You seem to be claiming that if a truck doesn't have at least a 300+ mile range (typical ICE) then it is pointless.

I am straight up saying that there is great point to a Tesla-BEV level truck, even if it's range is half a Model S.

> The more expensive trucks are usually heavy duty trucks that are used to haul things around.

You are thinking of the F250s, F350s, the Silverado 2500/3500s, etc.

I am talking about the F150s and 1500s that are luxury trim. And on that note...

> A Denali is an SUV, not a truck.

Yes, the [Denali line](http://www.gmc.com/denali-luxury-trucks-suvs-crossovers.html?seo=goo_%257C_2012_GMC_Retention_%257C_GMNA%257CUS%257CGMC%257CGOOG%257CS%257CBP%257CA%257CBMM%257CRTN%257CGMC%257CDIV%257C%2528null%2529%257C%2528null%2529%257CDenali_%257C_General_%257C_%252Bgmc%2520%252Bdenali) includes a few SUVs.

But it also includes the [Sierra 1500 Denali](http://www.gmc.com/sierra-denali-pickup-truck.html), which is a $50k+ luxury pickup truck that I have at least two coworkers (at a tech company) who commute in.

> I said the Teslas have a cooling deficiency.

Citation? Maybe you can run the motors at full power indefinitely, but you usually can't run an ICE motor at peak power indefinitely, either.

Plus with ICE it's much harder to slowly back off the juice and change the power characteristics on the fly when compared to electric.

> I'm pretty sure we went over the fact that towing requires large amounts of power to be produced over long periods of time, the Teslas cannot produce large amounts of power for long periods of time.

Again, citation?

While the Model S doesn't have a factory hitch, I know folks who have towed modest loads with theirs with an aftermarket hitch without issue.

There's also a few in the Rav4 EV community (Model S motor) who have successfully used a hitch. And those are cars that don't officially support them.

And the Model X *will* have a factory hitch, so obviously Tesla disagrees with the claim that BEV cannot tow.

> It's a hybrid, we were talking about BEVs.

The point of me bringing it up was that if you had agreed the Volt-style powertrain could be a successful truck, it's a *VERY* small leap to rip the engine off, replace it with batteries, sacrifice range, and call it a BEV truck.

But since you disagreed, the point was moot anyways.

But in your disagreement you also backhandedly suggested that the Volt wasn't even a success as a car. I was simply providing the citation that yes, it is a success as a car.

> I don't care, ... my point is that nearly all of the people who buy trucks wont buy a BEV truck.

...

> I don't care about you, I'm talking about the vast majority of the people who buy trucks.

The luxury BEV market started with a $130k 2 seater sports car that naysayers figured had no purpose in the world, and that the market would be way, way too small to be worth making.

Instead Tesla sold every one they were willing to make, and they've retained their value on the aftermarket like no relatively new car ever has in the history of the automotive industry (suggesting that people love them).

Then when the Model S solidified, the same naysayers said there was no way there would be a market for that huge of a sedan with that limited of a range that couldn't even fuel up.

Again, the market was bigger than the naysayers suggested.

I don't care that you're a naysayer. I'm just happy they're working on it and that I can use my wallet to vote.

transport.comment:
response to your edit:

>Well, ok I'm going to have to give you 10 points for being an early adopter

I'm the second owner on the Roadster, though I did drive an EV in 2009, the MINI E.  Which is the precursor to the precursor to the i3/i8 program.  So I do have some insight into that, since I've been onboard with it from the very beginning.  I believe I had the first MINI E delivered on the West coast and the third in the country.  So my comments on the i program do not come from ignorance, though you may well disagree with my opinions, they are at least informed.

>but geez, bud the Roadster looks like an upscale kit car compared to the starship i8.

Uh, no, nobody says that, and by the way, one of the general rules of car forums is not to talk shit on people's rides, which is probably why your most recent comment was downvoted.  There's no need to be an ass, please.  You were talking shit before on what you thought my ride was, and now you're talking shit on another car which is my ride, so that's twice you've done it.

>If we're JUST talking performance, I'd be getting an Ariel Atom, get the looks AND the sweet howl of an ICE engine

We're "just" talking about performance, then you talk about two things that aren't performance?  And considering the start of this conversation was you (not me) bringing up 0-60 and no other performance metrics, then bringing up a car which is slower 0-60 than the Model S as the pinnacle of performance seems a bit odd :-P

Besides, I'd rather have the Wrightspeed X1 - get rid of the annoying belch of the ICE and gain even more performance as a result, with the same looks and cornering ability as the Atom :-p  Also, if you have a problem with kit cars, the Atom is almost the definition of looking like a kit car...

> unlimited range

I dunno what you're talking about, you're tethered to gas stations, that's a limitation on range.  You can't even fill it up at home.  Convenience is a pro for EVs, not a con.  From the outside it looks like a con, because you're used to doing things the way you've always done things, but the vast majority of EV drivers find charging instead of gassing up as a source of joy rather than limitation.  Plug-in hybrid drivers too - Volt drivers call it "gas anxiety" and will do anything they can to stop from having to use the engine, because using electricity is so much more pleasant and getting gas is a chore.  Whenever you end up getting an EV, you'll understand what I'm getting at.  Hopefully beforehand too.  I say this as a person who has experienced owning both gas and electric vehicles, and who knows a lot of people who have experienced both, and the story is pretty much the same for everyone.

transport.comment:
>I look at the Electrodynamics machine which clocks in at 3300 HP and 390 lbs and get very excited about what the field of performance electric cars is capable of producing, given better batteries.

That's amazing. Another impressive motor is the [electric motor in Formula E](http://i.imgur.com/Wj52lHx.jpg) that comes from the McLaren P1. I think it's about 55 lbs and 270 HP.

The company that made the motor in the DeltaWing DHX made a  [coffee mug size 80 HP motor](http://www.engineering.com/AdvancedManufacturing/ArticleID/11406/Tiny-Electric-Motor-Delivers-80-Horsepower.aspx)

I think Tesla saw decent efficiency gains in their newer [high efficiency drive unit](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4bg5mjPANck). 

Electric motors have been around for ever but EV's are a mostly newer use for them and it seems like there are a lot of companies with different ideas making gains on the technology.  McLaren didn't have experience in electric motors before they set out to make the P1 and they have a solid idea of what they are doing now. 

It's good to see all these companies working on competing ideas. In terms of battery technology I'm hoping we eventually pair them with large capacitors for really quickly charging a few miles worth of power. The same tech could be used to handle "bursts" of power beyond how fast the battery can discharge. 

Even without any improvement in battery chemistry there are still gains to be had in motor efficiency, capacitors, charging network etc. 

Lots of companies are throwing their hat (and budgets) into the ring right now.

The other model that's different is free charging in carparks, in this instance their job is to sell parking, so they're available to everyone.

transport.comment:
>Will the level 2 charger they install be compatible with future EVs or a more modern one if my wife eventually upgrades her car?

The level 2 charger will be J1772.

J1772 (or more accurately CCS, which I'll explain below) is the charging standard used by most cars, the main exception is Tesla (although those all include an adapter that allows them to use J1772).

So yes.

>What are the other "levels"?

Buildings are wired with AC power, however batteries need DC to charge, so the power needs to be converted using an expensive AC to DC converter.

AC Charging: The charging station delivers AC power to the car and the car converts it to DC using an internal AC to DC converter. This is great for home charging where the customer doesn't want to pay $4k+ for a charging station with an integrated AC to DC converter.

DC Charging: The charging station has its own AC to DC converter and delivers DC power to the car. This is great for fast charging where the car's integrated AC to DC converter isn't fast enough.

Here are the charging levels:

kW is a rate of power transfer, the number of kW can be roughly approximated as the same as the miles of charge gained in 20 minutes.

AC Level 1 (aka Level 1): AC Charging using a normal electric outlet, up to 1.92 kW allowed in the spec, although most cars are limited to 1.44 kW.

AC Level 2 (aka Level 2): AC Charging using medium power wiring, up to 19.2 kW allowed in the spec, although most cars are limited to 11.52 kW.

DC Level 1: DC Charging using medium power wiring, up to 80 kW allowed in the spec, although afaik no cars support this.

DC Level 2 (aka Level 3): DC Charging using high power wiring and the CCS connector, up to 1200 kW allowed in the spec, although no car supports that speed and the Bolt only supports 50 kW.

J1772 and CCS are charging plugs supported by many cars. The difference is that CCS has additional hardware that allows it to support DC Level 2 charging. So the charging station you'll install at home will have J1772, although the car has a CCS port.

>How do I know what chargers I can use around town if I am ever in a pinch?

Plugshare is an excellent tool for checking that. Just select in settings that your car can use J1772 and CCS, then it will show a map of public charging stations. You can click on the stations to see the kW rate of the stations. Level 3 stations will show up orange, level 1&2 will show up green.

transport.comment:
#This Information Did Not Age Well

Remember all those warning tags on electric shavers and hair dryers telling you not to get them too close to the basin? 

For those who are new to electric vehicles, taking them through a car wash or driving them on wet roads might seem a bit counterintuitive. 

But if youre worried splashing through a puddle in your brand-new EV may cause it to short-circuit, rest easy.

>###Can Electric Cars Get Wet?

Short answer: Yes. But dont use that as an excuse to drive through floodwaters.

Ben Warren, Nissans National Manager of Electrification and Mobility says:

>If youre not going to drive through it in a petrol car, dont drive through it in an EV, and vice versa.

Now that weve gotten that out of the way, Mr Warren says EV owners can rest easy knowing the components in their cars are completely waterproof.

>Normally, one of the first points of concern from people is that the battery is in the floor at the lowest point of the car.

>It is completely sealed, and thats critical because it has to keep out water and dust, which batteries dont like. Its actually a task to get [the battery] open. When we manufacture them, its on the basis that these things will never be opened.

Additionally, the high-voltage cabling and charging plugs are also heavy duty and completely sealed, Mr Warren says, while the car has technology enabling itself to shut down if it detects any damage.

>The batteries are very clever and can isolate themselves within fractions of seconds in the event of an accident or damage.

In fact, electric cars are possibly even more protected in wet weather than their internal combustion-engined (ICE) counterparts. 

>For ICE cars in wet weather, the biggest issue is getting water in the air box or exhaust system  when you think about vehicles getting water damage in the engine, it has typically come from the air intake or exhaust pipe.

>[Electric cars] dont have air intakes  they dont need oxygen for combustion  and theres no exhaust pipe.

> Do Electric Cars Have a Different Wading Depth to ICE Cars?

That depends on the type of car, but typically you can assume an electric vehicle will have the same wading depth as its ICE counterpart.

According to Volvo, the wading depth for its XC40 Recharge is 450mm  when driving with great caution and no faster than at a walking pace.

Thats the same wading depth as the regular Volvo XC40.

Even for electric cars that arent designed to go off-road, you can assume the vehicle has been tested in a variety of conditions. 

>With the Nissan Leaf, unsurprisingly, we dont have an official wading depth [because its not an SUV], but when we launched the original generation 10 years ago, they did a lot of actual submersion testing and drove the car through different depths of water to make sure there were no issues.

transport.comment:
>What qualifies for "original installation" being complete?

Sorry, but I don't have an answer for that. My guess is that means "when the installer is done," but I don't have any IRS support for that.

As far as I am aware, the IRS hasn't provided additional information to clarify the "original installation" subsection, but you should check the IRS documents compiled at [https://www.taxnotes.com/research/federal/usc26/25D](https://www.taxnotes.com/research/federal/usc26/25D) (right side under IRS Private Rulings and Advice) to be sure.

You may want to read [26 CFR 1.179-4(e)](https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/26/1.179-4), which defines "placed in service" for *business* tax credits. Obviously, that definition doesn't apply to the *personal* tax credit under section 25D, but it may help. The idea here is that "when the original installation of the item is completed" clearly means something different than "placed in service" because if they meant the same thing, Congress would have just used one of those phrases.  So, if someone can figure out what "placed in service" means, then we can figure out what "original installation" does *not* mean and that can help.

Ultimately, I'm sorry I don't have a clear answer for you. Accordingly, I recommend talking to an accountant, but I'm pretty sure an accountant will say "I don't know." However, an accountant can advise you on the risks of any particular course of action and that should help you in your decision making.

transport.comment:
I can try. As a disclaimer, i've had the car since the start of june, so only a few months so far. I also bought it as a store demo (5k kilometers on the odometer already), so some of the accessories in my car isn't the default stuff (rubber floor mats, trunk insert for additional compartment).  
It's the Design model, with extended range (only the Comfort and Design model is available in Denmark, and only with extended range).  
**From the worse aspects to the better:**  
**The software suite is still not mature**  
The software of the car is still lacking, which does reflect well that BYD is still a pretty new competitor on the market. Lots of smaller features seems to be lacking, and if you're used to something like Tesla, it's even more evident.   
We do get a general idea of upcoming stuff by looking at Australian / New Zealand accounts, as they get updates faster than we do (less regulation, no EU).  
While they are patching and updating with necessary features (Android auto was added somewhat recently here in Europe as an example), there's still some missing stuff:  
\- Car currently fogs while decompressing the AC compressor once you turn it off (a fix is out, coming later this month)  
\- The battery estimate is based entirely on your battery wattage, it doesn't reflect your driving habit (A update to this is coming later this month, although initial reports from the southern hemisphere indicates it still needs some work).  
\- The screens in the car changes very abruptly between day and night mode, but it's a very quick transition from day to night, and a very slow transition from night to day. In a real life scenario, passing under a bridge on the highway might instantly turn dark mode on, but it'll take you a few hundred meters before it's back to day mode. It's also a very abrupt change, where some fade between the modes would be great  
\- For some reason, turning the cars headlights from "Auto" to whatever manual setting, turns the monitor into Dark mode.   
\- Android auto is fully integrated and works well, but on a large 15" monitor is extremely obtrusive to start your car, try and get some heat / cooling going, only to be thrown into Android Auto as it start up. There's also no quick panels back to the BYD shell (which is also running on Android), so you have to navigate through panels in Android auto to get back to the shell, and from there you can head back into the climate control section. (There is a quicker way by turning off the system and then choosing climate controls from there, but it's still a good indication it needs some work). Adding a hotbar or some other quick access bar shouldn't be an issue, considering the screen size.  
\- Minor annoyance, the built-in navigation is pretty great so far, but it also tells you if you're going too fast, even if it's just 2 km over the speed limit (which you can easily reach due to the cars acceleration).  
**The software suite for the technical side, still needs some work**  
The car works fine for driving, but there's some features in the car that needs additional work before it'll be a good experience:  
\- The lane departure warning system (LDWS) is great on regular roads, but it turns the steering wheel into a parkinson experience on narrow roads, even when the car isn't too close to the lines. The "shake" of the steering wheel to notify that you've strayed too far to either side, becomes rather annoying quickly.  
\- The sign recognition is straight up useless in a lot of cases, and using ICC (Intelligent Cruise Control or whatever they call it) where the cars Cruise Control conforms to the speeds registered on signs, is simply not useable as a result.  
 \- It does not recognize Danish town signs (which means an automatic 50 kilometer zone)  
 \- It does not register more than the standard round sign with a red border, whereas Denmark uses both that, and a blue sign to indicate slow zones in city areas.  
 \- It oftens misreads signs. Especially on highways, it reads our 110 kilometer signs as 100 kilometers.  
 \- Weirdly enough, the built-in navigation suite is pretty flawless when it comes to speed recognition, so my hope is they build in some cross-over data exchange at some point.  
 \- For now, ICC is turned off in my car.  
\- Turning on the AC is easy through the menu, and if you've already set it to the correct temperature, having a physical button for "auto" to set the correct speed is pretty handy. What's not handy, is that setting it to "auto" removes the previously set exhaust areas (main fans, window fans, lower fans at the feet) to only blow on the main fans. I'd prefer it if respected the previously set areas, as i do enjoy getting cold air on my legs, but the auto button just removes this entirely.  
\- The Lane Keeping System (LKS) warning when you're not engaging enough with the steering wheel, is a bit too aggressive for my liking. I don't want to wrestle with the steering wheel on a straight road, just to get it to shut up, but that's often how it is. On longer trips, i have become actively tired in my wrists from having to keep the pressure on the steering wheel.

housing.comment: I heard Shultz speak on this subject last October at Stanford (see if you can YouTube the panel discussion moderated by Lesley Stahl).  He pointed out the the US military is at the forefront of advanced energy research, for example with battery storage and solar technologies working together.  He pointed out that today's wired soldier carries on average 22 pounds of batteries for all the devices they use, and he showed a camo cloth that was both a solar cell/fabric integration and a storage device.  I would't take Shultz for a fool on any level at all.  Green energy is good for many more things than merely saving the planet... for example, when solar plus battery storage plus electric car charging from this home system are just a little bit cheaper than today, we ALL go into the business of optimizing our wallets by turning each of our homes into a microgrid: When the price is highest, we sell our excess into the grid, and when the price is lowest (only if we need to top off) we buy our shortage from the grid.  And all this is managed by superb softwares on a learning thermostat like that made by Google's recent acquisition Nest, that not only manage your home's energy and water use (including optimizing price on your buys/sells), they will also provide your perimeter security and home entertainment.  Those functions are actually not all that hard, if you think about it your smart phone already has easily that computational power and more... the Internet of Things will optimize your wallet and help our national security, even if you don't believe in global warming.

If your system is a common grid-tied system, then everything works seamlessly and automatically. Your PV system feeds the grid during the day. Your house pulls from the grid as needed. housing.comment:
I think the biggest reason NOT to wait is that later installed solar systems are less likely to qualify for net metering. 

For example, the people in Hawaii who decided to wait, now no longer qualify for net metering.  

There wasn't any sort of warning of "hey, you guys have 1 year to get your permits in."  Instead, the government just issued an order saying all permits issued today and earlier get net metering and all permits issued tomorrow and later get a worse deal (about 1/2 credit for each kWh sent to the grid plus a higher minimum bill).  Moreover, that worse deal is only good for a limited number of users so the next round of people are stuck with not being able to send electricity to the grid at all.

I also think California is closing the door on net metering soon too.

So while I do agree that solar is dropping in price very quickly, I dont think that those lower prices and other technology increases will make up for a less favorable utility agreement for a user. 

Edit: there is some research to support that wind turbines may cause health problems.  Is this true? I don't know, but it should be part of an analysis to see whether someone should get a wind turbine instead of solar panels.  All other things being equal, I would go for the solar panels.

housing.comment:
>Diesel 0.05 per km.

So you're assuming diesel will stay fixed at today's low prices over the next 7 years? Yet you're at the same time assuming the cost of electricity will rise, despite /u/SCW--'s stated intention of getting solar panels and effectively fixing his cost of electricity for 30+ years.

Requiring a battery replacement at only 7 years is very unlikely for the Model 3. Tesla battery degradation has been very slow: ["After 100,000 miles, the typical Model S is projected to retain about 92 percent of its battery capacity and range."](http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1096801_tesla-model-s-battery-life-how-much-range-loss-for-electric-car-over-time) Typically ~70% capacity is a threshold at which owners will want to replace the pack, but that's completely at the whim of the owner. While I couldn't tolerate <70% capacity in my Leaf, since a Tesla has so much more range to start the car will still be quite usable even with 50% capacity or less.

>Servicing is probably more.

On what basis? Aside from tires and creature comforts like A/C, EVs require almost none of the maintenance that goes along with ICE cars. With 2 EVs over a combined 8 years of use I've had no maintenance to do except for 1 set of new tires and several tire rotations, and a couple cabin air filters.

>less resale value

Again on what basis? Tesla resale values have held up quite well. Some reports suggesting poor resale values for EVs in general are disingenuous, as they measure resale value against the posted sticker price for new cars rather than the effective transaction price after the effect of subsidies. My Leaf's sticker price in 2011 was $34k, but I actually paid $22k after federal and state incentives. So if you compare against MSRP, on paper the Leaf resale value fell 35% the day I bought it. I guess that would make a great headline for an anti-EV troll, but nobody's going to make a buying decision based off of such nonsense.

>Lack of charging sites.

Have you not heard of Superchargers? And with an EV your house is the charging site you use at least 90% of the time. Good luck making diesel with some panels on your roof and having it automatically pumped into your car while you sleep.

housing.comment:
For sure, obviously if you have the cash on hand to spend on the panels then you're going to get far and away the best return. 

I could easily qualify for a loan, my credit is more than good enough to do so. The issue is most solar loans I've come across are somewhere in the 4-5% interest range. Even taking into account all the tax credits and the SREC's that come along with owning your own panels. That interest rate is MASSIVE. And honestly kills a lot of your return value. Odds are the loan isn't paid off for 8-10 years. At that point you've probably accumulated several thousand in interest and if you want to go sell the house now, you'll 'maybe' break even with the increase in home value. 

Right now this is our "starter" home so to speak. We really only intend on being here for 10-12 years tops as long as things don't go horribly wrong in our lives over the next decade. So I think in our future home, I'll probably look into buying panels out right with cash on hand. 

But for the time being I think leasing is the best way to save a chunk of money over the short and long term. And also make the house more appealing for resale. Initially I thought the lease might be a detriment to resale but the more I think about the more I'm changing my thought process there. 

That thought process started because my father HATES solar panels and thinks they're awful. That said, most people under 30 have a wildly different opinion than that. In the next 8-10 years as solar becomes more and more normal in our everyday lives it won't be seen as a detriment. It could be to the point where people specifically look for homes that already have solar capability. Especially first time homebuyers who won't have the money to buy the panels themselves. It'll be a different generation, taking my 58 year old fathers opinion into account is kind of silly in retrospect. I'm not going to be selling my house to a 55-60 year old more than likely.

housing.comment:
There is a logic behind which voltage to run.  I was trying to find a good link to assist in explanation, but can't locate.  So I'll give you a brief outline, but you should try to find an absolute better verification.

The logic:

#1, the higher the voltage, the lower amperage
#2, the lower the amperage, the smaller wire size needed
#3, the smaller the wire size, the more impedance (internal resistance based on length of wire)
#4, the more impedance, the more voltage drop

It is much about the distance between the solar panels and the batteries.  If you are using only one panel, then the voltage of the panel is fixed, but you still need to be concerned about the voltage drop across the wire distance between panel and batteries. 

Where you buy your panel, the person there should be able to assist you with proper wire size per the distance needed versus voltage.  Google wire impedance, you will likely find a table that will give you a heading.

Sorry can't be more exact.  Good luck with project.

housing.comment:
The only difference I can find is the colour of the backsheet, the choice of which depends on your summer/winter temperatures and how much roof insulation you have.    
82% of the energy is converted to heat, a black surface (the 0.05 model) will radiate that energy away a lot easier than white, keeping the panel cooler and more efficient (PV panels have a negative temperature coefficient), but that heat is radiated onto your roof, if you don't have insulation you might have to use the airconditioning more often if it is hot, or not start the internal heater if it is just below comfy.    
If it is freezing the panels could be colder and that black surface will act like a heatsink from your roof, needing more internal heating, while the higher albedo of white will reflect more of that heat back onto the roof.

housing.comment:
If they are already paid off does that mean they are older and less effective?

That depends on how long they have been there. A lot of people will pay cash, that would be owned outright. You need to know how long they have been there. Typical panels have a 25 year usable life (80% output) now days, I am not familiar with older systems.

My understanding is that in NY the energy generated goes to the main grid and then we receive a credit from the energy company, is his correct?

Someone familiar with the area will have to help you there.

Does having solar panels on a roof mean the roof will need to be replaced sooner/harder more expensive to replace?

Not sooner, but it will require a removal/reinstall which could cost a significant amount $0.50-$.75 per watt is reasonable ($2500 for a 5kW system)

Should I ask if there is a warranty on the panels?

Yes. Most modern panels have a 10 year equipment warranty and 25 year output warranty (they wont produce less than 80% within 25 years and they will have a linear degradation)

Is there a gigawatt level (?) I should be looking for?

Kilowatts (kW) is what you would be sizing on a house. The largest solar power plants are typically in the 500 mW (.5 gigawatts). This is largely dependent on the usage of the house. We size our systems based on usage, not size of the house.

How do I know the panels actually work?

Most systems have monitoring set up through some form of app on their phone/web based. SolarEdge systems have this as an option, but not all. If the system has Enphase microinverters, you may have to look at the bill to make sure. Most centralized inverters will have a LCD display that should light up with the press of a button.

Any specific questions I should ask the owner?

I would want to know all the equipment on the roof. This would include the modules (panels) and what inverter system it is using. Not much preference in racking as long as it looks good to you. They should have some info on this, or at least a contract. Some less than honest companies do not leave a lot behind, but at my company we provide everyone with a branded USB drive will all spec sheets, system designs, permits, HOA approval, etc. Basically all the data they could need should we go out of business or they sell their house.


Source: I am the head of the sales department at a large Central Texas installer

housing.comment: Would that 23k solar system be completely off-grid? I would imagine not since you're not including batteries, so you'll still need grid power for nights and cloudy days. This makes all the difference. If your solar system is grid-tied it will not work if the grid goes down (safety measure to protect workers fixing the grid), so you won't be able to get power from your solar panels even if they are still producing. There are some inverters that will power an outlet or small panel if the grid goes down (such as the SMA Secure Power), or you'll have to invest in a battery backup system at significantly more cost. Even then, a normal size battery system will only power a critical load panel, not your whole house.

120% rule on the MSP is just one detail limiting you to a 7.6kw inverter on a 200a MSP ( unless the bus is rated higher than breaker).
You also often have utility interconnect rules for net metering which you should be verifying before settling in a size.    Often incentives like net metering are restricted for large size arrays.  Some utilities ( that are not oublicky traded like coops and municipal   utilities ) do not have to even provide net metering.  
You should also model the array with at a minimum pvwatts or solardesigntool. 
You also need to verify what fits and production from those azimuths and shadows.

If I take 1kwh out of the grid, I shouldn't have to generate 5kwh to pay for it, they should just let people turn the meter backwards and bill the difference each quarter (net metering)

My system will pay for itself within 2 years

housing.comment:
Regardless of whether the coming winter proves to be mild or severe, Americans are going to be paying a lot more just to stay warm.

In the midst of a global energy crisis, energy-driven inflation is here and most Americans are deeply concerned. Unfortunately, the energy policy now under consideration could make the situation far worse, rather than better.

From gasoline to heating oil and natural gas, energy prices have jumped over the past year and they are likely to remain high for the foreseeable future.

While Americans are feeling the pinch of higher energy prices, the situation is far worse in Europe.

In the United Kingdom, energy providers are going bust at an alarming rate as they deal with soaring energy costs, pricing caps, and the governments renewable fees to force wind and solar power onto the grid. The crisis is poised to leave many Britons experiencing a serious cost crunch just to keep warm.

In Germany, inflation is at its highest levels since the 1990s, with soaring energy costs correctly identified as the culprit.

Astronomical natural gas prices and a lack of secure supply have left governments and utilities across the continent begging for more Russian natural gas. Relying on the goodwill of Vladimir Putin to keep the heat and lights on is hardly a successful policy.

Worse still, Europes energy crisis appears to be largely self-made. The European rush to renewable power and determination to shutter fossil fuel capacity and investment in new production has come home to roost.

By starving investment in new natural gas production and closing much of its coal fleet, European consumers have been left with few options and soaring energy prices before the idealized grid and energy systems of the future exist. In other words, energy reality has caught up with pie-in-the-sky aspiration.

Europe is as clear a case study on the perils of an ill-conceived energy transition as one could hope for but dont put it past American policymakers to learn all of the wrong lessons.

Instead of recognizing that an accelerated transition poses a grave threat to energy security and affordability, too many leading Democrats see Europes struggles as a signal to only double down on a renewable-only future.

The only legitimate thing he said is the concern over the toxic manufacture of solar panels and maybe batteries. 

That said, if you're looking for acreage, how about people's roofs or back yards? 

And how about this, limit hours of operation to these buildings to when the sun is out! So that even if you don't have batteries, solar is taking care of 70%++ of the electrical needs. Simply reducing the power from gas/coal/nuclear is a good thing, no? 

Honestly, the powers that be are making solar impossible when it should be a slam dunk. 

I have a DIY system and a small power footprint. First thing is, get people to use less electricity. It's really simple actually. My DIY system is 750W and on average covers 50%+ of my utility bill. It cost me a little over $1000. I'm under the radar, no permits, no outrageous charges for installation. I've checked into doing this legitimately and best case is $7000. Fucking insanity.  Because no one will play ball. Everyone has their goddam hand in your pocket.

housing.comment:
Being off grid is always more expensive and more difficult than grid tied. In order of expense:

Grid tied solar without batteries. Probably half your budget. Your electric bill goes away. No need to change power use at all. Generator only during power outages.

Grid tied solar with batteries. Your full budget should accomplish this. (Half on solar, half on batteries). Your electric bill goes away. You can use the batteries primarily or use them only for backup, but the grid will fill in any gaps (long storms, etc....) so you always have power.

Full off grid. Over your budget (possibly double). Your power bill goes away including your connection fee, but you need more solar and batteries to account for bad weather or low solar periods (or you burn propane to charge the batteries during those times which could keep the system within your budget...maybe). Reliability may suffer since you do not have redundancy with the grid.

You mentioned the cost of Powerwalls. Frankly, they are pretty affordable for what they offer, which is a very well made and reliable system. You can do cheaper, but there are compromises which may not be worth the cost savings in your situation.

housing.comment:
Fossil fuels are subsidized. https://e360.yale.edu/digest/fossil-fuels-received-5-9-trillion-in-subsidies-in-2020-report-finds

Fossil fuels remain expensive. The costs of solar photovoltaics (PV), wind, and batteries have dropped near exponentially at a rate near 10% per year. The cost of solar PV has decreased by more than three orders of magnitude since its first commercial use in 1958. https://www.cell.com/joule/fulltext/S2542-4351(22)00410-X

The largest infrastructure cost is for enhanced grid capacity. In 2050, for example, our estimated electricity network annual expenditure for the Fast Transition is about $670 billion per year, compared with $530 billion per year for the No Transition. However, the expected total system cost in 2050 is about $5.9 trillion per year for the Fast Transition and $6.3 trillion per year for the No Transition. Thus, although the additional $140 billion of grid costs might seem expensive, it is significantly less than the savings due to cheaper energy. The essential reason that the Fast Transition is cheaper than the Slow Transition is because it realizes the cost savings due to cheaper energy soonerfaster deployment increases the probability of rapid progress in key green technologies, so that savings accrue for longer.

housing.comment: Yes. The utility company, looks at the city inspection results. To have a city inspection, you need a city permit because all the inspections are recorded under that permit.  Another baffling thing that I saw in the city permit database was some of the solar projects were abandoned because they failed the city inspection. The solar panels are just sitting on their roofs.  The solar salespeople must be accessing the city permit database to find out who has a working solar and no working solar. I use the Google Maps to find out who has solar in the neighborhood, then search they city permit database if their solar has a permit. If there is a city permit, I read the permit information to check if the solar passed the inspection and that the permitted solar project was completed. But then again, there are two more steps:  PTO then activation are needed after the passed city inspection. Therefore, a passed city inspection does not guarantee that the home with solar achieved PTO and activation. A lot of the homes with solar in the NEM1 era had solar installers that no longer exist today. So that is a flag that if there is a problem with the solar, no new  solar installer would repair the old solar system unless they remove the old solar system and install a new one. This is because solar installers do not want to take over or repair solar systems that were installed by another company.

Did anyone - Sunrun or the previous owner - explain how it works before you signed the contract to assume the lease? They should have, and you should have insisted on it. 

5kW is likely the rated DC power of the solar system, which means its the peak power the system can output at any time. Most of the time, the system will be producing less than that, depending on time of day and time of year. 

You need to get someone to explain your bill, how much savings you are getting from Sunrun, and how much you are paying them. Hard to do here without seeing all the details. And its very possible that this lease is a bad deal for you.

housing.comment:
Where I live, people still actively deny climate change, or say its not a big deal, or say they know its going to be problem for the next few generations but they hate having paying more money to try and fix things, so those generations can just deal with it. (All statements that have been made to me/within my hearing in the last **month** alone).  

My province is in the middle of a decade long drought and my city has been choked by smoke from forest fires all day. Last summer was one long never ending haze of smoke from fires (or frantic evacuations from said fires) and this looks to be the same. Heck, there were around 30 fires burning through the winter from last year that never stopped (I looked at the map back in Jan, the number was in the low 30s, but cant remember if 32 or 34, so a generalized number of low 30s was used here lol).  We had a brown Christmas pretty much province wide as well.  Whats shocking about this is that it was the same in my home town which is really north - we are used to having several feet of snow at Christmas. 

But we make most of our money off oil and gas because decades of successive conservative govts have linked our economy tightly to that industry and refuse to diversify. Heck, they just put a moratorium on new solar and wind farms, and made it harder for private citizens with solar panels to put electricity back in the grid.  Meanwhile we have brownouts and calls for reduced electricity use this summer from this same govt. 

Yeah, thats gonna work when everyone will have to stay indoors with AC running due to record temps and air filtration systems running to clean out the constant smoke!

Dont even let me get started on the govt deals with coal mining companies on the (formally protected) eastern slopes of the Rockies - the source of most of the freshwater for our province and the next one over.  Yes, they stopped opening new mines after public backlash. No, they did not stop the already approved mines from being opened and continuing to run in the environmentally sensitive area of the eastern slopes. (One is run by an Australian company that is not longer allowed to mine in Australia due to the amount of environmental damage they caused from their operations)

Yay, Alberta!

housing.comment:
This is a good question, but there are different dimensions of your particular home and AHJ that are more important to answer first. And those questions hit different when you are talking about PV systems, compared to Storage systems. And even differently when trying to combine the two.

A few commenters have hit some isolated great points, but are leaving out real details you should be concerned about, and when they finish with an ancecdote plus a name brand, it makes a situation where they are absolutely saying the truth; and yet it may be bad for your particular scenario.

For PV systems, theres in general 3 options from highest cost to lowest:
1. Micro inverter systems (E.G. enphase, SunPower-Enphase with a different sticker)
-Benefits of this system: are maximized in high shade that is chaotic that can ruin production on DC string inverters
- Risks are: more moving parts (1 inverter per panel) , more opportunities for failures on those parts, less stress on each part (theoretically) IQ7 & 8 are way way more robust than the gen 2-4 micros I spent so much time replacing in 2012-2014. They no longer use amphenol connectors, which may have been the problem all along.
- you are paying a premium in order to make up for it with better production in shady places.

2. optimizer systems (Solaredge)
-instead of using Micro inverters to convert Dc to AC at the panels (creating a parallel connection where output isnt impacted by voltage drop); optimizers act like buck boosters and manipulate the DC voltage from each panel as a cheaper solution to dealing with shade that crosses arrays 1-2 panels at a time. 
- optimizers are cheaper to produce and replace, and are kind of like a budget version of Microinverters. 
-still have same risk of equipment failure like Enphase, but not as costly.

* if you dont have shade, or have a consistent predictable shade line: you are wasting money paying for either of these because there arent any marginal benefits.
-with predictable shade, one can strategically design the strings though a combination series and parallel connections in order to minimize the impact of shade.
- caveat: both optimizers and micros can fail and allow the good parts of a string to produce while waiting for service. For DC string inverters when it goes down all panels attached go down.

3. DC string inverters ( Fromius, Sunny Boy, Tesla, many many options)
- if you dont have shade, any other brand you are just paying extra for something you dont need.

My two cents: 
-Despite almost unanimous recommendation for Enphase, all the criticism for Enphase is referencing salesman and their margins.
- while Im not saying they are wrong, I spent the first 5 years of installing solar always recommending Enphase based on all the sales points made in this thread. 
- for a lot of installers, especially newer ones that dont know it too well. Pro Micro inverter arguments are an easy way to sound like you know what you are talking about with limited knowledge of how PV systems work.
-optimizers were the next evolution, achieving similar goals but with less cost. 

1. I was literally that guy for both systems for almost ten years. At the end of the day. If you dont have shade you are extending your payback timeline for a premium product you just dont need, which will extend that period.
2. PV maintenance is a tough reality, and its expensive. You may not have the whole system go down with micro inverters, but you may run a long time with  partial system until enough of them fail to justify the cost of a company rolling a truck and having a crew come swap them. 
-back in the mid 2010s, first swap was 150$ and then 75$ for each additional inverter. Real cost of rolling. Truck and labor for workers is between 500-1000$ easily so youd need 5 minimum to fail to justify that work. 
-certainly the micros are way better engineered now, which is good.
- my first solar work was with a mom and pop shop that went out of business. I will never buy a system from an installer that isnt too big to fail. There is. Market for maintenance work on systems where the installer went out of business, but all of that is more of a premium that impacts your pay back period in the long run.

For Batteries:
1. Know your dang AHJ before even looking at options. If they have adopted NFPA 855 your max battery unit is 20KWH which is a major limit on what stacking you are allowed to do regardless of brand.
- where you can put them and spacing between can be severely restricted. Again no brands matter at this point. Are you allowed to put them where you want? If space is limited you may have to choose whatever option get the most KWH in that space. Or maybe pick smaller batteries because their physical dimensions better maximize the space.

**** not a dang person has mentioned the actual KwH usage associated with their home. I see 10, 5 , and 3 versions of batteries discussed, but how much do they hold?

Spending 20k on a sweet Enphase battery that only holds 10KWH is stupid if you can get 13.5 with a single Powerwall for half that, or 19.5KWH with 2 LG Resu batteries for 14-16k$

For ROI: no one said anything f about their electrical provider!!!!!!!

Your electricity plan should be number 1 before picking your system.

If you get 1 for 1 credit: PV system never should be more than 100% offset. And Batteries only help if you need backup for critical needs.

If You get fucked: (export credit < import cost per KWH; or NEM 3.0; or nothing for export)

-You make money off having enough battery storage to prevent any PV generation getting to the grid at a bad rate. Have enough storage to have electricity covered when no sunlight. This is determined but your specific circumstances, not someone In another state saying something worked for them.

If you are lucky and can fuck the others: VPP through multiple options ( I think Octopus energy is one), need circumstances like California or Hawaii where time of use is going down.
- you us storage systems to strategically charge and discharge based on market rates. These. Are chances to make money with the system. Some areas its amazing and others not worth it.
- if its worth it, then these are the scenarios where its worth paying for extra batteries/greater than 100% offset for. PV system.


Step 1: what is your energy usage and cost
Step 2: do you have any alternative electricity plan options that may enhance your return on system?
Step 3: do you have shade? What type?
Step 4: can you even install ESS? Where? How much space is available? 
Step 5:Use these parameters to pick your system: PV only, PV + storage, Storage only.  As well as what type of system would work best based on your local conditions.

* once you know these things, then you should look at different PV and Battery solutions. Its super easy to install the wrong system because these issues werent considered. Doesnt matter how big the company is, I wouldnt trust any of them to do this process. Unless they ask these same questions.

If you cant do batteries because of NFPA 855, you may be able to go crazy with PV and pick. Weird electric plan to achieve the same results financially as different systems.

Im shocked at how many people  are skipping solar and getting enough energy storage to get from 9AM-9PM without using grid, and then charging everything after with a free nights plan.

A year ago I may have agreed with everyone in this thread. But really the game has changed so much in the last year.

Just as price for solar is in terms of $/Watt, treat all battery solutions as $/KWH. No one has money to buy two different batteries and try them out. They will all tell you to go with the one they picked.

20k& for 10KWH does not equal 10k$ for 13.5 KWH. All battery solutions work. My first one was with lead -acid batteries (heavy as F) and an out back Radian all are legit. Dont pay 10$ a KWH if you can do five

Dont buy a battery bigger than 20KWH in an NFPA 855 zone. At the same time, using 3 8KWH small batteries that fit will get you more storage than going with a bigger battery  (15KWH) that only  fits one. If your space is like that then choose accordingly. 

Hope that was helpful and not too rambling and chaotic. Its really amazing whats happening with technology in this industry right now.

food.comment:
I just made [The Grit](http://www.thegrit.com/) style tofu last night:

* Cube 1 block tofu (dice sized)
* Heat your favorite cooking oil to med/med-hi
* Cook tofu until it starts to brown slightly
* Sprinkle in about 1/4 cup soy sauce, toss it around to coat
* Remove tofu from pan to strainer, wait 10-15 min.
* Wipe down pan, oil lightly, put over med-hi heat
* Cook tofu for another 5 min. add a bit more soy sauce
* sprinkle heavily with nutritional yeast until tofu is coated (I do 3-4 applications, because it soaks in)

Serve over rice w/steamed veggies. Cock sauce makes it awesome. It also seems to get even tastier overnight in the fridge.

food.comment:
What about all of the rabbits and field mice that suffer and are killed when grains and vegetables are harvested with modern machinery?  What about the animals that are poisoned from pesticides?  (And even organic produce uses pesticides - they are perhaps *less* toxic and don't contain inorganic compounds, but are detrimental to animal health nonetheless).  A vegan lifestyle certainly reduces the amount of suffering in the world, but it also still entails suffering.  Being the case that feeding a vegan diet to a cat still requires animals to suffer and be killed in the production of the food, and that such a diet also causes extreme, prolonged suffering for the cat, I don't think it's reasonable to say that feeding a cat a vegan diet is ethically preferable.

Moreover, as a vegan I would argue that one of the primary obligations of those who care for animals is to create an environment as close to the natural environment of the animal as possible.  It's fucked up to keep birds in small cages because it's in a bird's nature to fly.  It's fucked up to have greyhounds if you live downtown in a big city because it's in their nature to run freely.  And just like it's fucked up that cows in factory farms are fed meat byproducts simply because they're cheaper, it would be fucked up for somebody to feed their cat a vegan diet.

food.comment:
Here are some of the things that really made a difference for me in transitioning into a vegan diet

* Veganaise- Amazing vegan mayo substitute, I've given it to friends who weren't vegan and they didn't notice the difference. It's great by itself on sandwiches, or as a base to a lot of creamy dressings and sauces that you thought you would miss by becoming vegan (Ranch, Blue Cheese, ect.)

* Daiya brand cheese- This "cheese" comes in cheddar, mozzarella and pepperjack varieties, and it is great for vegan tacos/burritos, vegan pizzas, and anything else you would have used cheese for. it melts and acts like cheese would.

* Seitan- Cheaper than the lowest grade meat you can find, and loaded with protein. Easy to make yourself if you can find a whole foods or co-op that sells vital wheat gluten. Use anywhere you would have used meat.

* Almond milk- I never liked the taste of soymilk or other milk replacements, and then I tried almond milk. The vanilla flavor is amazing with cereal, and you can use it as a substitute for milk in recipes.

* Isa Chandra Moskowitz and Sarah Kramer- A vegan friend of mine gave me a couple of cookbooks by these two women (*Vegan with a Vengance* and *La Dolce Vegan* respectively) and they basically taught me how to cook. Loaded with information and tons of creative ideas to keep things from getting boring.

I promise I don't work for any of the above companies. I'm simply trying to pass down some things I wish I had known in the first week or two of becoming vegan, when I was struggling to think of new things to eat, and being unsure about which brands and products I would like, and which ones I would waste my money on. I'd also recommend hanging out with your vegan friends. Ask if you could come over for dinner, but ask to come early, so you can help them cook. The vegan friends I've made have been a wealth of information and support. Good luck to you!

(edited for spelling errors)

food.comment:
1. Being overweight generally has an association of ill health.

2. Being (considerably) overweight has been objectively shown to cause health issues.

Propaganda is going to show an ideal. There's no implicit shaming in not including fat people in propaganda, nor is there some sort of implied assertion that veganism is going to make you magically skinny. Note: This part addresses the simple omission of overweight people from propaganda/advertising materials.

Certainly there is vegan propaganda that does focus on the weight loss aspects, but as the author of the article herself notes "*Research has shown that veganism is indeed an important variable in reducing excess body fat*". 

*"If we consistently show thin people (or women, or whites, or higher socioeconomic status individuals), we are framing our movement as one meant for certain types of people, but not for others."*

So if there's no vegan propaganda with amputees displayed, that means amputees are going to think veganism isn't for them? I don't think that line of reasoning makes a great deal of sense.

food.comment:
The only direct vegan replacement for egg white protein is *soy protein isolate*, which I've also seen called *soy concentrate*.  It rivals egg whites for [protein quality](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PDCAAS).  Any [soy-based protein powder](http://eas.com/product/soy-protein-powder) will be made from this stuff, and [vegan protein bars](http://www.clifbar.com/food/products_builders/1230) will also be the equivalent of about four eggs (sans cholesterol!).

Figuring $2 for a dozen eggs, protein bars will be about 3x more expensive than eggs for protein, though of course they contain vitamins, minerals and healthy carbs that eggs do not.  Protein powders will be comparable to eggs, or a little cheaper.  Figure [$20 for 30 servings](http://www.bodybuilding.com/store/opt/100soy.html?MCID=CG-PLA-US&mr%3AtrackingCode=16F1AED0-BC1A-E111-973E-001517384908&mr%3AreferralID=NA&mr%3AadType=pla&mr%3Aad=29751536466&mr%3Akeyword=&mr%3Amatch=&mr%3Afilter=26441253562), and you're looking at about 10 dozen eggs-worth of protein, which is also close to $20.

Tempeh and tofu are great, but they are good mealtime foods to be eaten with other incomplete proteins rather than in a recovery drink.

To start, O'Soy isn't vegan. It contains milk byproducts. It's really made for people who are lactose intolerant, not people with ethical objections to dairy. food.comment:
Having "feelings" is different from having the ability to feel and perceptive. I'm not saying that they are mammals that have the exact same make-up as us, but I'm saying that they are sentient alongside animals and humans due to the very definition of sentient. Vegans say that their way of eating promotes the lessening of harm to sentient beings. Sentient beings are those of which that have the ability to feel or perceive things within their environment - and by definition humans, animals, and plants have this ability. That being said, if plants have the ability to perceive and feel, vegans are by definition consuming sentient beings. 

Just to show one example of how they react to their environment and stimuli: Plants have the ability to smell out prey due to fragrances, just as we humans or just as animals have a response to smell, a stimuli. [You can see an example of that here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yb_9X3I38N0). It's quite interesting. 

And for arguments sake, let's say that plants don't have this sentience due to the fact that you don't think they feel pain because they have a nervous system or just because they react to stimuli (which someone else stated) - well then we have the argument of the philosophical zombie. We must realize that not all aspects of human nature can be explained though physical means. Specifically, all aspects of human nature and perception can be explained from a neurobiological standpoint.  

> Even insects probably aren't sentient, they are biologically programmed to react in certain ways under certain stimuli.

Reacting and being able to feel things within your environment goes with the exact definition of sentient, regardless of programmability or not. If the creature is living and can perceive and feel things from its environment, then by definition that being is sentient. If the creature cannot feel or perceive things within its environment, it is then not sentient.

food.comment:
Just for encouragement, I was here a few months ago and was completely convinced that would be my permanent stance. I was like 75% vegan because I ate most of my meals with my vegan girlfriend, but I had so many meat/cheese cravings that I couldn't help but go get a burger every time I ate alone.

Then I had to come home from college for the summer where my family would cook nothing but meat for every meal, and I felt worse than I ever had in my life (both physically and mentally). I reached a point where I was just so sick of animal products being shoved down my throat that it gave me that last little push to become full-vegan.

In a way, I wish I could just "advise" transitioning vegans to go through what I did. Cutting down on animal products for a couple of months then suddenly being forced to only eat animal products for another couple of months just adds so much perspective to how much better it feels to be vegan. I used to be the pickiest eater on earth and refuse to eat anything other meaty/cheesy foods, but I genuinely get grossed out by that stuff now.

Some areas are easier than others, but being vegan anywhere in the US is very possible.

Typically, grocery stores are better with options in metro areas and worse in more sparsely populated rural areas. But just about 100% of grocery stores have beans, grains, veggies, fruits, pasta, etc.

food.comment: Well, its a good thing Ive been on here for awhile. It prepared me for eating out with some family members who didnt yet know I was vegan. A cousin made a joke about how you can tell someone is vegan because theyll always tell you.  And my sister said,Well, good for you, in a very snide and childish way, like shes twelve instead of 62.  I was prepared for the hostility about it because of being here and I just thought I was challenging their egos and their sense of being a good people and shrugged.  My 19 year old niece, on the other hand, is very open to the idea, and talked about the vegan foods she has tried with her vegan friends. Maybe Im just in the wrong generation, I thought.  Or Im still open to new ideas and ways of living.  Those people are just old and set in their ways.                                                                                                                              It was my first time eating out since the pandemic started.  We were at the Keg. I tried to order the Mediterranean Cauliflower which was listed as vegetarian without saying I was vegan by just asking for no dairy in it. The server then asked me if I was allergic and I said no, actually Im vegan. She then replied that the dish is vegan.  After she left, I wondered aloud why the menu didnt just say that and thats when the questions and snide remarks started. Ah well, Im sure theyll get used to it.

food.comment:
There is a lot of misinformation out there. In some cases, the greenhouse emissions related to a transition to solar have been grossly exaggerated by fossil-fuel interests. However, there is indeed an issue with how we go about the transition. It is absolutely not zero cost to the environment. Its not as bad a has been portrayed, yet is in need of novel solutions to minimize the impact. It will take time, but the entire supply chain for renewable energy can be adapted to reduce or eliminate greenhouse emissions. A major mining company in Australia has recently begun to replace all of their heavy equipment with electric. There have also been major advances in low carbon production of steel and concrete. Concrete can be made that binds to CO2 potentially leading to negative emissions. Don't fall for the lies.  
  
Actually, in many regards, energy is easy. Reducing agricultural emissions is going to be extremely difficult on the other hand.

food.comment:
I just wanted to agree with this comment. I went from eating meat, eggs, and dairy to going vegan over night. What made the switch really easy for me was watching the documentary Earthlings and then reading as many articles and watching as many videos as I could to learn about veganism. I never imagined that I would or could go vegan, but I'm SO glad that I did! 

The first week or two were a little challenging while I adjusted but after the second week it was like I unlocked some sort of power! I felt great about helping my animal friends, I felt great physically from eating clean foods, and I got tons of compliments from my coworkers who said they noticed a difference in me. Not only that but I had an abundance of energy and I found that I could wake up so easily in the morning without feeling groggy at all! 

So I recommend to start out by watching some documentaries, educating yourself, and if you're going to try going vegan then do it for AT LEAST 2 weeks. If you don't feel any different then it's up to you from there. But I haven't even wanted to touch meat or dairy since going vegan.

food.comment:
My SO is a vegan lifter/body builder and regularly posts pictures of his ripped body and vegan recipes. He's been vegan for over 15 years and at first he gets "mmmm steak/bacon/burger" comments from some douchebros, but he never rises to the bait and never acknowledges the haters except with replies like "you do what's best for you and I'll do what's best for me". Recently however, some of those douchebros are starting to ask him vegan fitness tips and how to reduce animal product consumption while achieving peak physical condition, because they felt that he wasn't an annoying militant vegan or dogmatic about it and were more comfortable with discussing a meatless lifestyle with him, since he never judged them for eating meat before. They've been nothing but courteous (so I shouldn't call them douchebros anymore) and a couple of them have been convinced to reduce animal consumption thanks to my SO. It's way manlier to stick to your choices than succumb to societal expectations.

tl;dr Be patient and secure in your choices and pay no heed to those who feel insecure enough that they feel the need to mock or ridicule your choices. Also, humble bragging about my SO because he's awesome and I love him.
